image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: It once seemed unlikely to ever happen, but today Australians will vote on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament

image.altText: People lining up on a footpath to enter a voting centre. Cars parked nearby, and a Voting Centre sign on the footpath

items.synopsis: Australians across the country are heading to the polls to vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Australians head to the polls to cast their vote in Voice to Parliament referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liberal Party Leader Peter Dutton will not front media today but spoke to 7's Sunrise and also took to social media to share his Voice referendum thoughts. Mr Dutton, one of the most prominent No proponents, told Sunrise he just doesn't think the proposal held enough detail. "It's a very significant change that's proposed to our constitution, and if I thought it was going to provide the practical outcomes in Indigenous communities, then it would be a different story," he said. "I just think it's going to be another layer of bureaucracy. "I think whilst instinctively you want to help Indigenous Australians, you want to make sure that if you're going to put a new chapter in the constitution that is permanent, that lasts there forever, no law that the parliament can pass can out-manoeuvre the words in the constitution, you can't change the constitution by an act of parliament, and that's why it's incredibly important to get it right." The Uluru Statement from the Heart, on which the Voice proposal is based, particularly asked for the body to be enshrined in the constitution for that reason, unlike other Indigenous advisory bodies like the NACC and ATSIC, so it can't be disbanded by the government of the day.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton spoke on Sunrise, but isn't expected to front the media again today

children.content: Liberal Party Leader Peter Dutton will not front media today but spoke to 7's Sunrise and also took to social media to share his Voice referendum thoughts.
Mr Dutton, one of the most prominent No proponents, told Sunrise he just doesn't think the proposal held enough detail.

"It's a very significant change that's proposed to our constitution, and if I thought it was going to provide the practical outcomes in Indigenous communities, then it would be a different story," he said.
"I just think it's going to be another layer of bureaucracy.

"I think whilst instinctively you want to help Indigenous Australians, you want to make sure that if you're going to put a new chapter in the constitution that is permanent, that lasts there forever, no law that the parliament can pass can out-manoeuvre the words in the constitution, you can't change the constitution by an act of parliament, and that's why it's incredibly important to get it right."
The Uluru Statement from the Heart, on which the Voice proposal is based, particularly asked for the body to be enshrined in the constitution for that reason,
unlike other Indigenous advisory bodies like the NACC and ATSIC
, so it can't be disbanded by the government of the day.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Asked by ABC News if there was a 'Plan B' if the Yes vote was unsuccessful, Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil said: "I think your question is a reminder of why we are having a referendum in the first place. "We have serious issues with Indigenous disadvantage. Think of the fact that we have an eight-year life expectancy gap between Indigenous and non-indigenous Australians, a First Nations child in this country is 11 times more likely to end up in foster care and a First Nations mum twice as likely to die in childbirth. "We shouldn't tolerate these problems and we can't tolerate them any longer," Ms O'Neil added. "First Nations people have told us that the way they want us to resolve this is by establishing a Voice to parliament so politicians like me get advice about how we can use their leadership to some of these deep seated, urgent problems for the country. "So before we get into the discussion about what next, I say to all of your viewers, if you haven't made up your mind, please understand how urgent and important this is. "There is nothing to fear here. It is an advisory body to parliament and a really positive opportunity for us to realise what is a beautiful part of our history and heritage and that is 65,000 years of first nations continuous culture in our country."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Home affairs minister asked what Plan B is if  Voice referendum fails

props.alt: A woman sits while wearing a white blazer.

children.content: Clare O'Neil says 'there is nothing to fear' when voting yes.
(ABC News)
Asked by ABC News if there was a 'Plan
B' if the Yes vote was unsuccessful, Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil said:
"I think your question is a reminder of why we are having a referendum in the first place.

"We have serious issues with Indigenous disadvantage. Think of the fact that we have an eight-year life expectancy gap between Indigenous and non-indigenous Australians, a First Nations child in this country is 11 times more likely to end up in foster care and a First Nations mum twice as likely to die in childbirth.
"We shouldn't tolerate these problems and we can't tolerate them any longer," Ms O'Neil added.

"First Nations people have told us that the way they want us to resolve this is by establishing a Voice to parliament so politicians like me get advice about how we can use their leadership to some of these deep seated, urgent problems for the country.
"So before we get into the discussion about what next, I say to all of your viewers, if you haven't made up your mind, please understand how urgent and important this is.

"There is nothing to fear here. It is an advisory body to parliament and a really positive opportunity for us to realise what is a beautiful part of our history and heritage and that is 65,000 years of first nations continuous culture in our country."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Charlotte Gore In a press conference at Old Parliament House in Canberra, Australian Electoral Commissioner Tom Rogers has made a last-ditch attempt to quash what he called "nonsense" misinformation on the Voice. He said he has been shocked at the "bizarre" and "nutty" conspiracy theories surrounding the ballot. "We run one of the most transparent voting systems in the world," he said. "A hundred thousand members of the community, who are the eyes and the ears of the community — thousands of scrutineers who watch everything that we do. "And please, if you've got a question ask a member of the AEC – don't believe that nonsense online." Mr Rodgers said whether the result of the referendum is known tonight will depend on how close the outcome is. "If there is a very large margin, we'll know the results of that this evening," he said. "[But] we've had something like 2 million postal vote applications – those votes have to come back before we can count them." Lines have formed outside polling booths across Canberra this morning, with two thirds of Canberrans expected to cast their votes in person today. About 119,000 Canberrans – or just over a third – have already pre-polled, in addition to the 25,000 that applied for a postal vote.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electoral Commission chief calls out 'bizarre' and 'nutty' conspiracy theories

props.alt: A man in glasses and an AEC vest speaks in front of voting booths

children.content: (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)
Reporting by Charlotte Gore
In a press conference at Old Parliament House in Canberra, Australian Electoral Commissioner Tom Rogers has made a last-ditch attempt to quash what he called "nonsense" misinformation on the Voice.
He said he has been shocked at the "bizarre" and "nutty" conspiracy theories surrounding the ballot.
"We run one of the most transparent voting systems in the world," he said.
"A hundred thousand members of the community, who are the eyes and the ears of the community — thousands of scrutineers who watch everything that we do.
"And please, if you've got a question ask a member of the AEC – don't believe that nonsense online."
Mr Rodgers said whether the result of the referendum is known tonight will depend on how close the outcome is.
"If there is a very large margin, we'll know the results of that this evening," he said.
"[But] we've had something like 2 million postal vote applications – those votes have to come back before we can count them."

props.alt: The stairs of Old Parliament House in Canberra, where a Voting Centre sign sits at the front door

children.content: (ABC News: Anthea Moodie)
Lines have formed outside polling booths across Canberra this morning, with two thirds of Canberrans expected to cast their votes in person today.
About 119,000 Canberrans – or just over a third – have already pre-polled, in addition to the 25,000 that applied for a postal vote.

image.altText: An aerial view shows a crowded roundabout.

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong urges Australians who are in Israel or the Palestinian territories and intend to leave to do so as soon as they can. Follow live.

title.children: Twenty Australians are trying to leave Gaza chaos as ground invasion looms, Penny Wong says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military says it has struck a Hezbollah target in southern Lebanon in response to the "infiltration of unidentified aerial objects into Israel" as well as an Israeli drone coming under fire in the area. The IDF earlier reported its aerial defences had intercepted two unidentified objects above the port city of Haifa, about 140 kilometres south of the border with Lebanon, as well as a single object above the nearby Arab-majority city of Shfaram.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF strikes Hezbollah after 'unidentified objects' enter airspace

children.content: Israel's military says it has struck a Hezbollah target in southern Lebanon in response to the "infiltration of unidentified aerial objects into Israel" as well as an Israeli drone coming under fire in the area.

The IDF earlier reported its aerial defences had intercepted two unidentified objects above the port city of Haifa, about 140 kilometres south of the border with Lebanon, as well as a single object above the nearby Arab-majority city of Shfaram.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel has denied accusations from a human rights group that it used white phosphorus in its strikes on Lebanon and the Gaza Strip over the past week. White phosphorus is a chemical element that ignites when it comes into contact with air, making it useful for producing aerial markers or smokescreens, but also dangerous to civilian populations as it can cause serious burns. Its use as a weapon against civilians is illegal under the 1983 Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons. "We deny those allegations. We have not made use of white phosphorus — not in Gaza and not in Lebanon," an IDF spokesman said in a statement. The accusation was levelled by the international NGO Human Rights Watch, which published an investigation into the reported use of white phosphorus munitions in Lebanon and Gaza on October 10 and 11, respectively. It cited analysis of video footage as well as interviews with two people who witnessed the strikes. Israel has previously pledged to limit its use of white phosphorus after coming under heavy criticism for firing shells containing the chemical over Gaza in 2008.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel denies using white phosphorus in Lebanon and Gaza strikes

children.content: Israel has denied accusations from a human rights group that it used white phosphorus in its strikes on Lebanon and the Gaza Strip over the past week.

White phosphorus is a chemical element that ignites when it comes into contact with air, making it useful for producing aerial markers or smokescreens, but also dangerous to civilian populations as it can cause serious burns.
Its use as a weapon against civilians is illegal under the 1983 Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons.
"We deny those allegations. We have not made use of white phosphorus — not in Gaza and not in Lebanon," an IDF spokesman said in a statement.
The accusation was levelled by the international NGO Human Rights Watch, which
published an investigation
into the reported use of white phosphorus munitions in Lebanon and Gaza on October 10 and 11, respectively.
It cited analysis of video footage as well as interviews with two people who witnessed the strikes.
Israel has previously pledged to limit its use of white phosphorus after coming under heavy criticism for firing shells containing the chemical over Gaza in 2008.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has urged Australians who are in Israel or the Palestinian territories and intend to leave to do so as soon as they can. Speaking in Adelaide, Senator Wong said about 825 Australians have so far left Israel and the Palestinian territories, but about 20 Australians are still seeking to leave Gaza. She also confirmed a second repatriation flight will arrive in Tel Aviv today to bring Australians to Dubai. "If you wish to leave, please do not delay … Please take the first available flight. Please do not wait for another option," she said. "I would emphasise that the situation on the ground is changing quickly, it is extremely difficult." Senator Wong said Australians still in Israel or the Palestinian territories should register with the DFAT crisis portal or call the government's 24-hour consular emergency centre on +61 2 6261 3305 for assistance.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Foreign minister says 20 Australians seeking to leave Gaza

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has urged Australians who are in Israel or the Palestinian territories and intend to leave to do so as soon as they can.
Speaking in Adelaide, Senator Wong said about 825 Australians have so far left Israel and the Palestinian territories, but about 20 Australians are still seeking to leave Gaza.
She also confirmed a second repatriation flight will arrive in Tel Aviv today to bring Australians to Dubai.

props.alt: A middle-aged woman with short grey hair looks serious as she speaks in front of a row of "Vote Yes" placards.

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the situation in Israel is extremely difficult.
(ABC News)
"If you wish to leave, please do not delay … Please take the first available flight. Please do not wait for another option," she said.
"I would emphasise that the situation on the ground is changing quickly, it is extremely difficult."

register with the

title.children: The public sentiment shift that turned the tide of the Voice referendum

title.children: The man who blew the whistle on whistleblower Kathy Jackson and revealed her as a fraud

image.altText: Costa, who has long hair and a bushy beard, smiles against a blue backdrop, with images of a cheese toastie and kimchi.
